Terminology.text: Benign epithelial change characterized by cells with enlarged nuclei but maintained nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio

Clinical Issues.text: May occur anywhere in female genital tract
Most commonly reproductive age (pregnant) but may be seen in women at any age on oral contraceptive or hormone replacement therapy

Macroscopic.text: Does not typically form mass lesion
May extensively involve polyp(s)

Microscopic.text: Usually focal but occasionally extensive with micropapillary and cribriform growths
Affected glands show spectrum of nuclear and cytoplasmic changes
Cells often protrude into gland lumen (hobnail appearance)
Enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic to vacuolated cytoplasmMaintained nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
sub_points: Maintained nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio

sub_points: Intranuclear cytoplasmic pseudoinclusions common

Microscopic.text: Mitoses typically absent

Ancillary Tests.text: Napsin-A, HNF-1-β frequently positive
Reduced or loss of ER expression
Low MIB1 proliferative index

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Before considering diagnosis of microglandular hyperplasia in postmenopausal women, endometrial and (less commonly) endocervical adenocarcinoma with microglandular features should be excluded
Presence of any degree of mitotic activity or cytologic atypia in lesion with microglandular architecture strongly suggests diagnosis of adenocarcinoma
Some microglandular hyperplasias may show extensive fibrinous exudate, and this finding should raise possibility of associated plasminogen deficiency

Terminology.text: Malignant mesenchymal neoplasm composed of skeletal muscle with various degrees of differentiation

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: DICER1-pleuropulmonary blastoma familial tumor predisposition syndrome: Pulmonary blastoma, cystic nephroma, ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors (intermediate or poorly differentiated), cervical botryoid embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS), nodular thyroid hyperplasia or thyroid carcinoma, and others

May have focal fascicular growth
Fetal-type cartilage (up to 50%)
Preexisting entrapped glands

Small primitive (embryonal) or polygonal (alveolar) cells and rhabdomyoblasts (including strap cells) ± anaplasia

sub_points: Pulmonary blastoma, cystic nephroma, nasal chondromesenchymal hamartoma, ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors (intermediate or poorly differentiated), cervical botryoid embryonal RMS, ciliary body medulloepithelioma, pineoblastoma, pituitary blastoma, nodular thyroid hyperplasia or thyroid carcinoma, others

Incidence.text: < 1% of soft tissue sarcomas in adults
Embryonal RMS most common histologic subtype

Age.text: Embryonal RMS: Children to young women (but wide age range)

Presentation.text: Vaginal bleeding or mass protruding through os

Treatment.text: Simple hysterectomy or local excision ± chemotherapy (especially if stage I)
Radical surgery and adjuvant therapy (if advanced)

sub_points: Factors associated with better survival: Younger age, no metastases, embryonal histology, negative lymph nodes, surgical resection

sub_points: Radical surgery does not provide survival benefit over local excision + chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Embryonal RMS in adults: < 20% survival

Usually 3-4 (up to 30) cm

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Overall good prognosis with conservative management
In patients with tumors confined to cervix, adenosarcoma staging system superior to uterine sarcoma staging system to predict survival
Genetic testing may be indicated in patients with cervical embryonal RMS, as may be associated with germlineDICER1mutations

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Densely cellular zone (cambium layer) of primitive cells under epithelium is characteristic of embryonal RMS
If abundant glandular component, consider müllerian adenosarcoma
In any polypoid lesion with prominent stroma, scrutinize at high magnification for hypercellular areas with primitive cells
Other tumors in lower female genital tract may be positive for skeletal muscle markers (myogenin)

Abundant eosinophilic to vacuolated cytoplasm with preserved N:C ratio ± nuclear pseudoinclusions and smudgy chromatin
ER, PR positive, MIB1 low; p16 negative

Typical Lobular Endocervical Gland Hyper.text: No epithelial tufting or nuclear stratification
Small nuclei with no nucleoli or mitotic activity

Radiation-Induced Atypia.text: No nuclear pseudostratification, apical mitoses, or apoptoses

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Low-power morphologic surrogate features of HPV-associated AIS include abundant apical mitoses and apoptotic bodies
Normal endocervical glands in reproductive-aged women may have scattered mitoses but do not show nuclear pseudostratification, hyperchromasia or apoptotic bodies, as seen in AIS
AIS should always be considered when there is intestinal differentiation, as intestinal metaplasia is exceedingly rare in normal endocervical glands
Focal glandular involvement by high-grade squamous dysplasia/carcinoma in situ should be favored over AIS when nuclei do not overlap and are rounded with no associated intracytoplasmic mucin
SMILE should not be confused with squamous cell carcinoma in situ; even though at low power both show nuclear "stratification," cells display cytoplasmic variably sized vacuoles with mucin in former
Comparison of architecture of neoplastic glands to preexisting glandular architecture helpful in distinguishing in situ from invasive adenocarcinoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Most cervical SCC are HPV associated; however, minor percentage is HPV independent; before making latter diagnosis, all modalities to exclude HPV-related tumor recommended
Be aware of spectrum of morphologies of SCC before making diagnosis of more unusual carcinomas
In contrast to other organs, lymphoepithelial-like SCC of cervix are not EBV related
Tumors with squamotransitional morphology have been reported to be more often associated with low-risk HPV
Lymphovascular invasion is best evaluated at periphery of tumor; be cautious in diagnosing lymphovascular invasion in absence of tissue invasion

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Diffuse p16 positivity indicative of HR-HPV infection; however, as it can be diffusely (+) in both LSIL and HSIL, it should not be used for grading
p16 may be used to separate HSIL > > LSIL from reactive cytologic changes
p16 positivity in isolation is not diagnostic of HPV-related process; thus, morphology is key to diagnosis
Prominent cytologic atypia or atypical mitoses in basal layers is diagnostic of HSIL
Striking underlying stromal inflammation may be seen in HSIL and not necessarily be indicative of invasion; however, close examination of these areas required

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: 3 major species causing human infections:Schistosoma mansoni,Schistosoma haematobium,Schistosoma japonicum
Pathology is caused by host tissue reactions against antigens ofSchistosomaeggs, which induce predominantly Th-2 immune responses

Clinical Issues.text: Worldwide distribution; prevalence is highest in sub-Saharan Africa
Mortality related to schistosomiasis is low
Likelihood of complications and morbidity correlate with parasite burden, duration of infection, site(s) of infection

Microscopic Features.text: Inflammatory granulomatous reaction and eosinophilic infiltration, which result in local tissue destruction and fibrosis
S. mansoni(average: 140 x 66 µm): Elongated/oval egg with a lateral spine
S. haematobium(average: 143 x 60 µm): Elongated/oval egg with a terminal spine
S. japonicum(average: 90 x 70 µm): Oval egg with a small lateral spine/knob

Definitions.text: Greek: "Skhistos" (divided, cloven) + "soma" (body)

Early chronic infection: Granulomatous inflammation and ulcerations result in development of pseudopolyps, which may mimic malignancy
Longstanding infection: Fibrosis and calcification of bladder wall, bladder neck obstruction; associated with bacterial superinfection, acute renal failure, and development of bladder cancer

Men: Infection may involve epididymis, testicles, spermatic cord, or prostate

Prognosis.text: Mortality related to schistosomiasis is low

Radiographic Findings.text: Chest: Fine miliary nodules corresponding to granulomatous reactions toSchistosomaeggs

Gross Examination.text: Liver: Symmer clay pipestem fibrosis: Enlarged fibrotic portal tracts with severe portal fibrosis due to schistosomiasis

Ova Detection in Clinical Specimens.text: Eggs can be detected in urine and stool specimens by microscopy
Extent of egg shedding may vary widely; multiple specimens may be needed for diagnosis

Serologic Testing.text: Commercial assays are available against various schistosome antigens, e.g., ELISA, radioimmunoassay, Western blot, complement fixation
Sensitivity and specificity depend on serologic technique, antigen used, and intensity of infection
Tests are generally negative during acute infection and turn positive 6-12 weeks after exposure
Cannot distinguish between prior infection and active disease

Antigen Testing.text: Qualitative assays that measure parasite antigens in blood, stool, &/or urine have been developed
Sensitivity and specificity vary with assay techniques and targeted antigens but are reported to be as good as or better than stool or urine concentration methods for egg detection

Molecular Diagnostics.text: PCR assays for stool, urine, and serum have been developed but largely remain as research tools

Coccidioidomycosis.text: Lacks ova and shows spherules with endospores

Tuberculosis.text: Positive for acid-fast stain and lacks ova and eosinophilic inflammation

Sarcoidosis.text: Lacks presence of ova and eosinophilic inflammation

Neoplasms.text: Lack ova and exhibit histologic morphologies consistent with malignant or benign neoplasms

Presentation.text: Moist, red, eczematous-appearing plaque(s)Raised white areas of hyperkeratosis on erythematous background resulting in characteristic cake-icing or strawberries and cream appearance
sub_points: Raised white areas of hyperkeratosis on erythematous background resulting in characteristic cake-icing or strawberries and cream appearance

Presentation.text: May mimic inflammatory process (dermatitis), seborrheic keratosis, pigmented condyloma, or pigmented vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia

Treatment.text: Wide local excision
Lymph node dissection, if invasive component > 1 mm

Surgical treatment challenging due toMisleading visual assessment of margins, ~ 30% of grossly negative margins will be pathologically positiveCommon deceptive appearance on frozen sectionMargin status not predictive of recurrence, as tumor commonly multifocal (skip lesions)
sub_points: Misleading visual assessment of margins, ~ 30% of grossly negative margins will be pathologically positive
Common deceptive appearance on frozen section
Margin status not predictive of recurrence, as tumor commonly multifocal (skip lesions)

Treatment.text: Topical bleomycin, 5-fluorouracil, carbon dioxide laser, imiquimod, or systemic retinoids if recurrent in situ disease
Treatment of underlying malignancy if secondary EMPD
Distant metastatic disease treated by multiple chemotherapy agents and targeted therapy based on next-generation sequencing (e.g., against HER2/neu amplification,TP53andPIK3CAmutations)
Mohs micrographic surgery may be associated with lower recurrence risk (limited experience)

Prognosis.text: Favorable outcome if localized and noninvasive (~ 80% cases)
Disease-specific survival for microinvasive (≤ 1 mm) similar to noninvasive disease (88-100%)
Factors associated with worse prognosisNodules on clinical examinationElevated CEA levelsDermal invasion (> 1 mm)Lymph node metastases (66% mortality)Underlying malignancy (secondary EMPD)
sub_points: Nodules on clinical examination
Elevated CEA levels
Dermal invasion (> 1 mm)
Lymph node metastases (66% mortality)
Underlying malignancy (secondary EMPD)

Terminology.text: Neoplasm with neuroectodermal differentiation composed of epithelioid to polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic and granular cytoplasm

Clinical Issues.text: May be multifocal within vulva or coexisting with other locations (Noonan syndrome)
Uncommon local recurrences (2-5%) and rare malignant behavior (1-2%)

Macroscopic.text: Nonencapsulated but often well-defined subcutaneous or dermal < 5-cm nodule with white and firm cut surface

Microscopic.text: Pushing, nodular, or infiltrative growth
Diffuse, nested, or corded growth of polygonal cells
Abundant granular cytoplasm with PAS-D-resistant bodies
Associated pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia ~ 30%
Malignant if ≥ 3 of following features: Necrosis, cell spindling, vesicular nuclei with large nucleoli, > 2 mitoses/10 HPF at 200x, high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, and pleomorphism

Ancillary Tests.text: S100, SOX10, nestin, calretinin, and inhibin positive
NSE, CD68, CD63, CD56, TFF3, and MITF often positive
Loss-of-function mutations in ATP6AP1 or ATP6AP2

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Smooth muscle tumor with granular change

Definitions.text: Neoplasm with neuroectodermal differentiation composed of epithelioid to polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, with low risk of recurrence

Incidence.text: May be multifocal within vulva or coexisting with other locations (Noonan syndrome)

sub_points: Labium majus > > clitoris or mon pubis

Treatment.text: Local excision with negative margins to avoid recurrence

Prognosis.text: Excellent outcome for most patients
2-5% local recurrences and 1-2% malignant behavior

General Features.text: Nonencapsulated but often well-defined, subcutaneous or dermal nodule
White, firm cut surface with rare ulceration

Histologic Features.text: Pushing, nodular, or infiltrative margins
Diffuse, nested, or corded patterns of loosely cohesive cells
Collagen bands often present between nests
Entrapment of adnexal structures (if in labium major)
Common perineural involvement
Associated epidermal hyperplasia; striking, pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia in ~ 30%

Cytologic Features.text: Polygonal to spindle (latter if malignant) cells
Abundant granular cytoplasm with PAS-D-resistant bodies (phagolysosomes)
Small, dark (benign) to vesicular nuclei with nucleoli (malignant)

Malignant if ≥ 3 of following features: Necrosis, cell spindling, vesicular nuclei with large nucleoli, > 2 mitoses/10 HPF at 200x, high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, and pleomorphismIf 1-2 features: Atypical GCT
sub_points: If 1-2 features: Atypical GCT

Immunohistochemistry.text: S100, SOX10, nestin, calretinin, and inhibin positive
NSE, CD68, CD63, CD56, TFF3, and MITF often positive; HMB-45 negative
p53 expression > 10% of cells if malignant
Ki-67 positive < 1% of cells; but often in > 30% if malignant
Neurofilaments, GFAP, desmin negative

Electron Microscopy.text: Intracellular granules containing myelin figures and fragmented rough endoplasmic reticulum

Molecular Findings.text: Loss-of-function mutations in ATP6AP1 or ATP6AP2

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (If Superficial.text: Lack of maturation of squamous epithelium ± koilocytosis

Smooth Muscle Tumor With Granular Change.text: Fascicles or sheets (if epithelioid) of cohesive cells without intervening collagenous stroma

Reactive Changes With Abundant Histiocyt.text: History of infection, trauma, or cesarean section
Foamy macrophages admixed with inflammatory cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Tangential sectioning of HPV-associated VIN involving skin appendages should not be overinterpreted as invasion

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Minor components of SCNEC and LCNEC can occur in each of 2; in some instances, distinction is difficult, and designation as NEC is most important
If NEC admixed with other histologic subtypes, advisable to provide percentage of each component
SCNEC may be negative for all neuroendocrine markers; synaptophysin and CD56 most sensitive markers, although CD56 nonspecific
To establish diagnosis of LCNEC, positivity for at least 1 neuroendocrine marker is required

Scattered positivity for neuroendocrine markers within nonneuroendocrine carcinomas may be seen due to presence of isolated neuroendocrine cells but should not be interpreted as neuroendocrine neoplastic component

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Depth of invasion should be measured from surface to deepest point of invasion; however, this information may not always be relevant when dealing with adenocarcinomas with Silva pattern A of invasion
Before making diagnosis of separate endometrial and endocervical primaries, extensive sampling may help identify transition between 2 tumors

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Apical mitoses and basally located apoptotic bodies seen at 40-100x magnification represent morphologic surrogates of HPV-associated adenocarcinoma

Before making diagnosis of primary endometrioid adenocarcinoma of cervix in absence of precursor lesion, exclude mucin-depleted HPV-associated adenocarcinoma, as it shows nuclear pseudostratification and may mimic morphology of endometrioid adenocarcinoma

Villoglandular adenocarcinoma is now included within category of usual-type HPV-associated adenocarcinoma, as it is often seen with usual-type endocervical adenocarcinoma displaying apical mitoses and apoptotic bodies; however, it should be noted in report, as often exophytic and invasion may be absent

Close attention should be paid to exclude component of micropapillary carcinoma in HPV-associated adenocarcinoma, as it has an with aggressive behavior; this pattern should be noted in pathology report for prognostic purposes

Goblet cells and Paneth cells may be seen in intestinal-type HPV-associated adenocarcinoma and HPV-independent gastric-type adenocarcinoma, and p16 may be diffusely positive in latter; thus, diagnosis should be made based on morphologic appearance of nongoblet cells, associated precursor lesions, as well as HPV status
Before establishing diagnosis of primary signet-ring cell carcinoma of the cervix, metastases should always be excluded, especially when no usual-type adenocarcinoma is seen

Invasive stratified mucinous adenocarcinoma should be included in differential diagnosis of adenosquamous and squamous carcinoma, and these tumors were likely misdiagnosed as such in past; at higher power, stratified cells have abundant intracytoplasmic vacuoles, and no intercellular bridges are identified
HNF-1-β and napsin can be positive in mucinous carcinomas of cervix; thus, relay on morphologic features, p16, and, if necessary, HPV status

Some HPV-associated adenocarcinomas lack typical morphologic features of different categories of HPV-associated adenocarcinomas but still have brisk mitotic activity and abundant apoptosis and are diffusely p16 positive and HPV positive

HPV-associated adenocarcinomas can display Silva pattern A, B, or C (latter more frequent in micropapillary and invasive stratified mucinous carcinomas), in contrast to all HPV-independent adenocarcinomas that are associated with a Silva pattern C of invasion

Staging.text: Stage should be based on parameters available from pathologic material
It is important not to provide different gross and microscopic measurements for tumor size
Horizontal tumor extension has little prognostic value in stage I tumors (microscopic disease)
If different specimens, deepest point of invasion in 1 single specimen should be noted
Term "microinvasive" carcinoma should not be used in reporting invasive adenocarcinoma
Although Silva patterns have not been fully adopted, it is important at least mention it in comment
Quantification of lymphovascular invasion may be important, as it has been found in endometrial carcinomas, correlating with risk of lymph node metastases
Lymphovascular invasion does not upstage tumor even when outside uterus
Endometrial and adnexal involvement by adenocarcinoma does not change FIGO stage but should be reported
Multiple isolated or aggregates of tumor cells within lymph nodes should not be aggregated as single measurement but should be reported

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Exophytic component of tumor should not be used for depth of invasion measurement
In poorly differentiated tumors, keratinization and desmosomes provide clues to diagnosis
Tangential sectioning of adnexal structures involved by VIN should not be misinterpreted as invasion
Before considering diagnosis of sarcoma, possibility of spindle squamous cell carcinoma should be excluded
As significant morphologic overlap between HPV-related and -independent squamous cell carcinoma occurs, immunohistochemistry useful in subclassification

Early stromal invasion may be difficult to diagnose in superficial biopsies; presence of paradoxical maturation and loss of basal membrane and cell polarity helpful in distinction from in situ disease

Goal of Consultation.text: Determine if a mass-forming lesion of fallopian tube is benign or malignant
Diagnose suspected tubal pregnancies by identifying products of conception

Incidence.text: Deciduosis: Involves almost all ovaries at term

Treatment.text: If limited: Analgesics
If significant: Androgens, progestins, GnRH agonists, &/or aromatase inhibitors
If severe: Laser ablation or excision

Prognosis.text: Excellent except if secondary malignancy

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Possibility of Lynch syndrome should be considered in setting of ovarian endometrioid adenocarcinoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Consider possibility of synchronous or metachronous extraovarian endometrioid carcinoma before making diagnosis of metastatic endometrial carcinoma

Some endometrioid carcinomas can show extensive WT1 positivity, and as they also can haveTP53mutations, morphology and other molecular tests may be required to separate high-grade endometrioid from high-grade serous carcinomas; high-grade serous carcinomas typically show high-grade nuclear atypia with poorly formed glands, absent nuclear polarity, and no luminal border

Even though synchronous endometrial and ovarian endometrioid carcinomas are almost always clonally related, they mostly behave as independent tumors when applying typical morphologic criteria (depth of invasion of endometrial tumor, lymphovascular invasion and size of endometrial tumor, presence of precursor in ovary)
Do not mistake endometrioid carcinoma with stromal lutein cells, which can be calretinin (+), as Leydig cells in Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
Before making diagnosis of primary mucinous carcinoma of ovary, consider possibility of endometrioid carcinoma with mucinous differentiation (look for typical patterns of endometrioid carcinoma)

Seromucinous carcinoma currently included within category of endometrioid carcinoma as there is poor diagnostic reproducibility, it often displays endometrioid areas &/or squamous differentiation, and it shows similar immunohistochemical and molecular profile to endometrioid carcinoma
If endometrioid carcinoma associated with adenosarcoma, which may show high-grade features or stromal overgrowth, prognosis related to latter, as endometrioid carcinoma typically low grade
Inhibin, SF1, and FOXL2 best sex cord markers in separating sex cord-stromal tumor from endometrioid carcinoma
Glypican-3 should not be used to distinguish yolk sac tumor from endometrioid carcinoma, as it is (+) in both; furthermore, yolk sac tumors may be PAX8(+)

In separating breast from endometrioid carcinoma, GCDFP-15 [when (+)] and TRPS1 are most helpful; GATA3 does not exclude possibility of metastatic breast carcinoma if negative; remember, mammaglobin can be (+) in gynecologic epithelial malignancies
TTF-1, GATA3, ER, and PR are most helpful in distinction of mesonephric-like carcinoma from endometrioid carcinoma (with exceptions)

Clinical Issues.text: Most common malignant germ cell tumor (~ 50%)
~ 70% stage I at diagnosis; low recurrence rate < 10%

Macroscopic.text: Solid, white to tan, soft, lobulated cut surface

Microscopic.text: Nests of cells intersected by fibrous septa (alveolar pattern) typically containing lymphocytes
Other patterns: Diffuse > macronodular > insular, corded, trabecular > tubular > pseudoglandular > single cells
Cells with abundant pale cytoplasm; large, rounded to squared-off nuclei; ≥ 1 prominent nucleoli
Epithelioid histiocytes/granulomas (~ 20%)
Syncytiotrophoblast cells (isolated or in groups) in 3-5%
May be seen in association with gonadoblastoma

Ancillary Tests.text: CK20, EMA, high molecular weight keratin, SOX2, glypican-3, and CD30 (-)
AE1/AE3 and NSE may be very focally (+)
D2-40 (membranous and cytoplasmic) frequently (+)
OCT4, SALL4 (nuclear), CD117 (membranous), PLAP (+)
i12p or 12p amplifications;KITamplifications (~ 30%)

Definitions.text: Malignant primitive germ cell tumor with no pattern of differentiation

Genetic.text: Rare association with gonadal dysgenesis (Turner or Swyer syndrome, testicular feminization, and triple X syndrome)
Extremely rare association with Cowden and Down syndromes

Incidence.text: Most common malignant germ cell tumor (~ 50%)

Age.text: Most common in 2nd and 3rd decades (average: 19 years)

Presentation.text: Incidental (particularly when complicating gonadoblastoma in dysgenetic gonads)
Hypercalcemia rarely (2nd most common tumor with this finding among young women)
Serum CA125, hCG, LDH, and PLAP levels frequently elevated

Treatment.text: Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy if stage I
Adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy if advanced

Prognosis.text: Very good, as most tumors are stage I at diagnosis, and high-stage tumors are responsive to chemoradiation~ 70% are stage I at diagnosisLow recurrence rate (< 10%)Pelvic soft tissues, fallopian tube, peritoneum, and retroperitoneal lymph nodesRecurrences typically within first 2 years

Recurrences typically within first 2 years

Terminology.text: Malignant primitive germ cell tumor showing variety of distinctive patterns, ranging from primitive gut and mesenchyme to derivatives of extraembryonal (secondary yolk sac and allantois) and embryonic somatic tissues (intestine, liver, and mesenchyme)

Clinical Issues.text: < 30 (mean: 19) years except if associated with surface epithelial tumor (in latter poor prognosis)
Most stage I and good response to chemotherapy

Macroscopic.text: Honeycomb (multiple small cysts) if polyvesicular vitelline

Microscopic.text: Meshwork of irregular channels (reticular), which expand to form cysts of different sizes (microcystic/macrocystic) > > papillae > > solid > > other
Papillae with central blood vessel (Schiller-Duval body) in ~ 1/3 of cases (typically reticular)
Glandular variant: Nonspecific, including goblet and Paneth cells (up to 50%), endometrioid-like (supra- and subnuclear vacuoles), and, rarely, intestinal (primitive cells with cribriform growth)
Hepatoid variant: Typically minor component

Polyvesicular vitelline variant: Conspicuous cysts, sometimes with eccentric constriction (simulating subdivision of primary yolk sac vesicle) often lined by flattened cells embedded in cellular or paucicellular stroma

Ancillary Tests.text: AFP, PLAP, glypican-3, LIN28, SALL4, ZBTB16, GATA3 (+)
AE1/AE3, HNF-1β (common), PAX8 (up to 25%) (+)
CK7 and EMA , if (+) only focal

Definitions.text: Malignant primitive germ cell tumor showing variety of distinctive patterns, often with variable endodermal differentiation, ranging from primitive gut and mesenchyme to derivatives of extraembryonal (secondary yolk sac and allantois) and embryonic somatic tissues (intestine, liver, and mesenchyme)

Dedifferentiation.text: May rarely arise from primary surface epithelial tumor (no 12p abnormalities but somatic abnormalities)

Incidence.text: ~ 20% of malignant germ cell tumorsAs common as dysgerminoma in first 2 decades
sub_points: As common as dysgerminoma in first 2 decades

Age.text: Postmenopausal if associated with surface epithelial tumor (rare)

Treatment.text: Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
Adjuvant chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Favorable due to response to chemotherapy even with extraovarian extension (> 30% of cases)> 90% survival, if stage I
sub_points: > 90% survival, if stage I

Prognosis.text: Worse prognosis if arising from surface carcinoma

Fleshy, friable, gray to tan, solid and cystic cut surface > cystic > solid
Honeycomb (multiple small cysts) appearance, if polyvesicular vitelline component
Necrosis ± hemorrhage common
May be associated with mature cystic teratoma or less often with surface epithelial tumors

Histologic Features.text: Most commonly meshwork of irregular channels (reticular) that expand to form cysts of different sizes (microcystic/macrocystic)
Papillae containing central blood vessel (Schiller-Duval body) present in ~ 1/3 of cases (typically in reticular areas)
Cellular papillae with conspicuous budding may occur
Long ribbons, sometimes in drape-like/festoon pattern
Solid, labyrinthine, festoon patterns less common

RAS,PAX8::PPARGrearrangement (follicular carcinoma)

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Prognosis of IT is related to grade and stage but has greatly improved after chemotherapy era

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Gross assessment is crucial in distinction between immature from mature (cystic) teratoma, as former is typically larger (average: 16-17 cm), and it is solid or solid and cystic (but not purely cystic ± Rokitansky nodule) even though it may have hair and sebaceous material
Very important to sample IT extensively; not only to assess amount of immature neuroepithelial tissue in order to grade appropriately but also to exclude other germ cell components
In IT, neuroepithelium is only immature element assessed when gradingFetal cartilage can also be seen in mature cystic teratoma and should not be considered immature (embryonal) element
sub_points: Fetal cartilage can also be seen in mature cystic teratoma and should not be considered immature (embryonal) element

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Malignant transformation into CNS-type tumor can occur and should be excluded
Immunohistochemical stains do not play role in diagnosis of IT

Presence of microscopic foci of yolk sac neoplasia (< 2 mm) or syncytiotrophoblast cells does not affect prognosis of patients with ITPresence of syncytiotrophoblast cells is not evidence of choriocarcinoma, as it is lacking typical biphasic growth
sub_points: Presence of syncytiotrophoblast cells is not evidence of choriocarcinoma, as it is lacking typical biphasic growth

Terminology.text: In situ germ cell neoplasia with intimate admixture of germ cells and incompletely differentiated sex cord cells arranged in distinctive nested pattern

Macroscopic Anatomy.text: Complex organ with multiple regions: Ectocervix, endocervix, lower uterine segment, endometrium, myometrium, and serosa
Ectocervix: Distal end of uterus, typically covered by stratified squamous epithelium
Endocervix: Tunnel-like lumen of uterine cervix, lined by mucin-secreting pits
Lower uterine segment: Triangle-shaped transition from endocervix to uterine corpus
Endometrium: Uterine mucosa composed of glands and stroma
Myometrium: Muscular wall of uterus composed of layers of smooth muscle
Serosa: Thin lining of body and fundus of uterus; covers portions of uterus that are not retroperitoneal

Microscopic Anatomy.text: Ectocervix: Stratified squamous epithelium overlying fibrous stroma
Transformation zoneSquamocolumnar junction that lies between ectocervix and endocervixZone identified by squamous metaplasia of endocervix; migrates during reproductive years
sub_points: Squamocolumnar junction that lies between ectocervix and endocervix
Zone identified by squamous metaplasia of endocervix; migrates during reproductive years

Microscopic Anatomy.text: Endocervix: Simple, columnar mucinous epithelial cells line endocervical pits that extend into fibrous stroma
Lower uterine segment: Transition between endocervix and endometrium; admixtures of endometrial and endocervical glands and stroma may be seen in this region

Endometrial glandsColumnar epithelial cells that vary from simple to pseudostratifiedEpithelium may contain vacuoles (secretory) or be ciliatedFunctionalis: Superficial endometrial layer, lost during menstruationBasalis: Deep layer of more monomorphic glands that regenerates functionalis after shedding
sub_points: Columnar epithelial cells that vary from simple to pseudostratified

Functionalis: Superficial endometrial layer, lost during menstruation
Basalis: Deep layer of more monomorphic glands that regenerates functionalis after shedding

sub_points: Middle circular layer heavily vascularized and contains arcuate arteries

Microscopic Anatomy.text: Serosa: Thin mesothelial lining of uterine corpus and fundus

Age-Relation Variations.text: During puberty, endocervical epithelium migrates toward ectocervix (ectropion) and then is slowly replaced by squamous epithelium during reproductive years
Endometrial atrophy: Inactive, cystically dilated glands may be present after menopause

Metaplasia.text: Squamous metaplasia: Occurs along transformation zone
Ciliated (tubal) metaplasia: Common; occurs in endocervix and endometrial glands
Mucinous metaplasia: Uncommon metaplasia of endometrium; typically consists of simple to stratified, columnar mucinous epithelial cells

Pitfalls and Artifacts.text: Glandular compression, simulating hyperplasia, may be seen following biopsy
Suction created by biopsy instruments may lead to "gland-in-gland" artifact
Exfoliation artifact leads to epithelial shedding, which can mimic serous carcinoma
Arias-Stella effect may closely resemble carcinoma due to marked atypia and glandular crowding

Terminology.text: Biphasic low-grade tumor composed of benign müllerian (rarely up to carcinoma in situ) glands and low-grade malignant stroma (often homologous)

Clinical Issues.text: Recurrence rate of 30-50% mostly related to sarcomatous overgrowth, high-grade stroma, myometrial invasion, or underdiagnosis

Macroscopic.text: Polypoid mass filling endometrial cavity
Solid and cystic, white to gray to tan cut surface

Glands with phyllodes architecture, cystically dilated or, less commonly, small
Proliferative-type endometrial epithelium (most common) with variable cytologic atypia
High-grade stromal cytologic atypia uncommon

Sarcomatous overgrowth: > 25% of tumor composed of only neoplastic stroma, typically high grade

ER, PR, and CD10 minimal if sarcomatous overgrowth

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Cellular endometrial polyp or polyp with features overlapping with müllerian adenosarcoma

Worse prognosis in older women

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Most müllerian adenosarcomas (except if high grade or stromal overgrowth) are associated with good prognosis, as typically polypoid with minimal infiltration

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Diagnosis of low-grade adenosarcoma should be suspected if "recurrent" endometrial polyps
Müllerian adenofibroma diagnosis should be avoided; no longer included in WHO 2020, as these tumors likely represent underdiagnosed low-grade müllerian adenosarcomas or polyps with unusual morphology
Finding focal increased cellularity around endometrial glands is not sufficient to establish diagnosis of low-grade müllerian adenosarcoma
Extensive sampling of "fleshy" areas should be performed to exclude sarcomatous overgrowth (associated with dismal prognosis)
Even though sarcomatous overgrowth is typically high grade, it can rarely be low grade

Finding of high-grade stroma does not qualify for sarcomatous overgrowth if it does not occupy > 25% of tumorHowever, its presence should prompt additional sampling (as it is often associated with sarcomatous overgrowth) as well as documentation in report (as it is associated with poor outcome)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Some molecular alterations reported in müllerian adenosarcomas overlap with those of completely unrelated tumors; thus, morphologic correlation is key in establishing correct diagnosis, especially at metastatic sites

Benign and Low-Grade Endometrial Stromal.name: Benign and Low-Grade Endometrial Stromal Tumors

Terminology.text: Endometrial stromal nodule (ESN): Absent, to at most minimal, myometrial invasion (< 3 mm and < 3 protrusions) lacking vascular invasion
Endometrial stromal sarcoma (ESS): Endometrial stromal tumor (EST) with myometrial &/or vascular invasion
EST with limited infiltration: More infiltration of adjacent myometrium than allowed for ESN but no overt permeation, as seen in ESS and absent lymphovascular invasion

Clinical Issues.text: 90% 5-year disease-free survival if stage I or II ESS; 70% at 10 years

Microscopic.text: ESN: Well-circumscribed, pushing margins ± small irregularities, as lobulated or finger-like projections (< 3 in number and < 3 mm in size) into myometrium; no lymphovascular invasion
ESS: "Blue" islands with irregular contours permeating myometrium (tongue-like) ± vessel invasion
ESN and ESS: Diffuse monotonous growth of small "blue" cells with arterioles ± collagen plaques

Variants: Smooth muscle and rhabdomyoblastic differentiation; myxoid and fibroblastic; epithelioid with sex cord-like, glandular elements; with clear, granular, rhabdoid cells, pseudopapillary with adipose tissue or bizarre or multinucleated cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: In curettage, endometrial stromal proliferation can only be diagnosed as EST, as evaluation of margins not possible
If ESS involves ovary, inquiry about prior hysterectomy mandatory; EST is by far more common in uterus

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: In hysterectomy specimens, endometrium should be entirely submitted for histologic examination to exclude adenocarcinoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: PTEN and PAX2 immunohistochemical stains, while helpful in understanding pathogenesis of endometrial neoplasia, should not be used as routine diagnostic markers, as 1/2 of EINs retain PTEN and 1/3 retain PAX2 expression
Finding intraglandular nonvillous papillae should not be misinterpreted as well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in absence of confluent glandular growth
Presence of crowded but individually defined glands helps distinguish EIN from well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, which characteristically has complex architecture
If focus is not diagnostic for EIN (< 1 mm or close to but does not meet 50% threshold for gland crowding), follow-up sampling indicated as "gland crowding" associated with subsequent EIN (20%)
EIN/AEH can involve adenomyosis and should not be mistaken for invasive carcinoma

Terminology.text: Malignant mesenchymal tumor of smooth muscle lineage with variable morphology and degrees of differentiation

Clinical Issues.text: Typically > 40 years of age with peak at 50 years

Macroscopic.text: Solitary large mass; variably circumscribed margins
Gelatinous appearance if myxoid

Microscopic.text: Spindle: Usually long intersecting fascicles (often cellular)
Epithelioid: Diffuse, nested, corded, plexiform growths (> 50% of cells)
Myxoid: Abundant intercellular myxoid background
Cytologic atypia and mitotic activity
Tumor cell necrosis (abrupt transition from viable to necrotic tumor with no intervening area of granulation tissue; atypical cells within areas of necrosis are atypical)

Infarct-type necrosis (characterized by interface between necrotic and viable tumor being composed of granulation tissue often with associated hemorrhage; necrotic areas have mummified appearance with no viable perivascular tumor)

Ancillary Tests.text: Smooth muscle actin, desmin, caldesmon, transgelin (+)
ER, PR, and AR (less frequently) positive
p16, p53, CD10, BCL2, WT1, c-kit often positive

IMP3 and HMGA2 frequently (+); PLAG1(+) if myxoid
HMB-45 and cathepsin-K can be (+); melan-A (-)
BCOR and Pan-Trk may be (+); cyclin-D1 (-) (rare exceptions)
FrequentTP53,RB1, HMGA2, andATRXmutations

Definitions.text: Malignant mesenchymal tumor of smooth muscle lineage with variable morphology and degrees of differentiation

Environmental Exposure.text: May be related to prior radiation therapy

Genetic Susceptibility.text: Increased incidence in patients with retinoblastoma, Li-Fraumeni, or hereditary leiomyomatosis/renal cell carcinoma syndrome

Incidence.text: ~ 40% of LMS in female patients originate in uterus

Age.text: Typically reproductive and postmenopausal (> 40 with peak at 50 years)

Presentation.text: Symptoms and signs related to extrauterine extension or metastases
Nonspecific symptoms, including weight loss, weakness, ± fever
Paraneoplastic syndromes (myasthenia gravis, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, multiple seborrheic keratosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome) may occur

Natural History.text: Extrauterine disease at time of diagnosis in ~ 35%

Treatment.text: Radical hysterectomy (± adnexectomy &/or lymph nodes)
No obvious benefit from radiation or chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Pathologic stage strongest predictor of outcome, but, in general, histologic or molecular parameters not good predictors
Common recurrences (45-73%) even in stage I tumors
Recurrences within 2 years in spindle LMS and even up to 10 years in myxoid and epithelioid LMS
Tumor fragmentation (morcellation) associated with increased risk of recurrences, especially peritoneal
Alterations in DNA damage repair genes associated with poor outcomes

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: When evaluating cytologic atypia in smooth muscle tumors, use 10x objective, and, if possible, compare cytologic features of tumor with surrounding myometrium
Distinction between tumor cell and infarct-type necrosis may be difficult and interpretation not reproducible; thus, important to evaluate cytologic atypia and mitoses
Extensive sampling always useful, especially in epithelioid and myxoid LMS to uncover areas with increased mitoses, which can be key to establishing correct diagnosis
Threshold of myxoid background to diagnose LMS, as myxoid ranges between 30-60% but recommended to use lower threshold, as tumors are aggressive

When using immunohistochemistry in differentiating smooth muscle tumors from their mimics, panel of antibodies should be used, as overlapping results with single antibodies are not infrequent (e.g., PEComa may express desmin, and LMS may express HMB-45)
Molecular studies may be helpful when immunostains are not definitive in distinguishing among tumors
Loss of FH staining in smooth muscle tumor does not preclude malignancy

Macroscopic.text: Typical: Bulging white to minimally pink, firm, whorled cut surface

Leiomyoma with diffuse perinodular hydropic change: Multiple nodules separated by edema

Dissecting leiomyoma (including cotyledonoid leiomyoma or "Sternberg tumor"): Placenta-like appearance with multiple bulbous red nodules, typically attached to each other by thin membranes, dissecting through myometrium
Diffuse leiomyomatosis: Diffuse, regular thickening of myometrial wall due to multiple and confluent leiomyomas < 1 cm
Diffuse peritoneal leiomyomatosis: Variable number of nodules with firm, white, whorled cut surface scattered in pelvis/peritoneum, typically < 2 cm, although rarely some may be large
Intravenous leiomyomatosis: Multiple worm-like plugs of white to slightly pink or tan tissue filling and distending myometrial &/or parametrial soft tissues outside of leiomyoma (if present)
Benign metastasizing leiomyoma: Well-circumscribed, firm, white, and whorled nodules typically in lungs

Unusual growth patternsDissecting leiomyoma (including cotyledonoid leiomyoma or Sternberg tumor): Swirled growth of spindle cells with prominent vessels and hydropic change separated by delicate fibroblastic matrix with large muscular vessels, often dissecting myometrium and extending into serosaDiffuse leiomyomatosis: Poorly defined, closely packed small nodules composed of fascicles of spindled cells with tendency to merge with each otherLeiomyoma with vascular invasion: Typical leiomyoma or leiomyoma variant with microscopic intravascular growth within tumorIntravenous leiomyomatosis: Endothelial covered protrusions of smooth muscle resembling either typical leiomyoma or variants outside confines of leiomyoma, if present; subendothelial proliferation of benign smooth muscle may merge with intravascular tumorDiffuse leiomyomatosis peritonealis: Well-defined nodules composed of fascicles of spindled cells with no cytologic atypia or brisk mitotic activity; decidual cells may be admixedBenign metastasizing leiomyoma: Relatively well-defined nodule of spindle cells with fascicular growth and benign cytologic features, most commonly in lung where alveolar spaces may be entrapped

Dissecting leiomyoma (including cotyledonoid leiomyoma or Sternberg tumor): Swirled growth of spindle cells with prominent vessels and hydropic change separated by delicate fibroblastic matrix with large muscular vessels, often dissecting myometrium and extending into serosa
Diffuse leiomyomatosis: Poorly defined, closely packed small nodules composed of fascicles of spindled cells with tendency to merge with each other
Leiomyoma with vascular invasion: Typical leiomyoma or leiomyoma variant with microscopic intravascular growth within tumor

Intravenous leiomyomatosis: Endothelial covered protrusions of smooth muscle resembling either typical leiomyoma or variants outside confines of leiomyoma, if present; subendothelial proliferation of benign smooth muscle may merge with intravascular tumor
Diffuse leiomyomatosis peritonealis: Well-defined nodules composed of fascicles of spindled cells with no cytologic atypia or brisk mitotic activity; decidual cells may be admixed
Benign metastasizing leiomyoma: Relatively well-defined nodule of spindle cells with fascicular growth and benign cytologic features, most commonly in lung where alveolar spaces may be entrapped

Calretinin, WT1, D2-40 (+) in mesothelial cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Sampling of smooth muscle tumors if unusual gross appearance crucial, especially if epithelioid or myxoid
If typical gross appearance but worrisome microscopic appearance, leiomyoma with bizarre nuclei most likely
If worrisome gross but typical microscopic appearance, most common scenario hydropic, apoplectic, or red degeneration
If worrisome gross and microscopic features, most likely leiomyosarcoma
Leiomyoma variants may coexist (i.e., highly cellular and mitotically active, bizarre nuclei and fat)
If differential diagnosis on gross exam between leiomyoma with hydropic change and myxoid smooth muscle tumor, squeezing of tumor will extrude watery fluid if hydropic change

Important to be aware of margins in partly myxoid leiomyomas, not to misconstrue nonmyxoid areas as myometrium and consider tumor to be infiltrative, and thus malignantIn these tumors, evaluation of nonmyxoid areas helpful in classification
sub_points: In these tumors, evaluation of nonmyxoid areas helpful in classification

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Collagen bands, although typical of endometrial stromal tumors, may be seen in leiomyomas, including intravenous leiomyomatosis
Evaluation of cytologic atypia should be performed at 10x; helpful to compare with surrounding myometrium
Before counting atypical mitoses as such, consider possibility of karyorrhectic nuclei, especially in leiomyomas with bizarre nuclei if typical mitoses uncommon

If infarct-type necrosis not well developed, may be difficult to be certain about nature of necrosis; in those cases, carefully evaluate cytology and mitotic activity to separate benign from malignant tumors

Important to be aware of "zonation" phenomenon in apoplectic leiomyomas as areas close to hemorrhage/infarction may show brisk mitotic activity, myxoid change, and plumper cellsp16 may be extensively (+) and Ki-67 may be increased in next to infarct-type necrosis and may raise concern for leiomyosarcoma
sub_points: p16 may be extensively (+) and Ki-67 may be increased in next to infarct-type necrosis and may raise concern for leiomyosarcoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Vascular leiomyomas may show minimal expression of smooth muscle markers due to dropout of smooth muscle cells

If differential diagnosis between epithelioid smooth muscle tumor and PEComa, do not perform only smooth muscle markers or HMB-45PEComas may be actin, desmin, &/or caldesmon positive, especially if associated with spindle componentSmooth muscle tumors may be HMB-45 and cathepsin positive
sub_points: PEComas may be actin, desmin, &/or caldesmon positive, especially if associated with spindle component
Smooth muscle tumors may be HMB-45 and cathepsin positive

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Cleft-like spaces and thick-walled blood vessels are very characteristic of highly cellular leiomyoma and rare in endometrial stromal tumors
Periphery of highly cellular leiomyoma often shows interdigitation with myometrium but typically subtle merging in contrast to sharp outlines of large tongues of low-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma
Highly cellular leiomyomas with small "seedling" cellular leiomyomas in adjacent myometrium can be misconstrued as low-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma

In differential diagnosis of highly cellular leiomyoma and endometrial stromal tumor, not recommended to use CD10 or IFITM1 in isolation but as part of panel, including CD10, desmin, and caldesmon, as highly cellular leiomyomas may be CD10 positive
If differential diagnosis between smooth muscle tumor and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor, ALK/ROS should be part of immunohistochemical panel
FH loss in smooth muscle tumor not necessarily indicative of leiomyomatosis-renal cell carcinoma syndrome; most tumors associated with somatic mutations
Uterine morcellation may be responsible for peritoneal seeding and secondary peritoneal leiomyomatosis

Terminology.text: High-grade endometrial carcinoma with nuclear pleomorphism and papillary, glandular, solid growth, or combination thereof, often associated with prominent budding of noncohesive cells

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: May be seen in patients with breast carcinoma (BRCA1/BRCA2mutations)

Clinical Issues.text: Survival up to 90% if confined to endometrium

Macroscopic.text: May not be not visible

Microscopic.text: Papillary, pseudoglandular, solid growths; slit-like spaces
Irregular, branching papillae with cellular budding
May involve only endometrial polyps or replace preexisting endometrial glands
Prominent nuclear pseudostratification; absent nuclear polarity or luminal border, noncohesive cells
High-grade nuclear atypia and brisk mitotic activity

Ancillary Tests.text: p53-mutated staining pattern: Typically diffuse (> 80% of cells strong nuclear), rarely null pattern (deletion mutation) or only cytoplasmic (+); p16 diffusely (+); very high Ki-67 index
WT1(+) in up to 1/3, typically weak/patchy with exceptions
± HER2 overexpression (pattern/intensity correlates with amplification status)

Definitions.text: Serous carcinoma: High-grade endometrial carcinoma with nuclear pleomorphism and papillary, glandular, solid growth, or combination thereof, often associated with prominent budding of noncohesive cells

Serous endometrial intraepithelial carcinoma: Partial or complete replacement of preexisting endometrial glands &/or surface endometrium by serous carcinomaAlthough proposed as precursor of serous carcinoma, can be associated with extrauterine disease; therefore, terminology may be misleading and is not recommended
sub_points: Although proposed as precursor of serous carcinoma, can be associated with extrauterine disease; therefore, terminology may be misleading and is not recommended

Definitions.text: Minimal serous carcinoma: Invasion of endometrial stroma but not myometrium (not included in most recent female genital tract tumors WHO)

Environmental Exposure.text: May be related to prior radiation or tamoxifen therapy
No association with obesity, hypertension, or hyperestrogenism

Hereditary Predisposition.text: May be seen in patients with breast carcinoma (BRCA1/BRCA2mutations)

Presentation.text: Postmenopausal bleeding or serosanguineous vaginal discharge
Peritoneal carcinomatosis (with minimal endometrial disease) rare
Signs and symptoms related to extrauterine spread (lung, brain metastases)

Treatment.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral adnexectomy and surgical staging
Adjuvant radiation &/or chemotherapy (except for some stage I tumors polyp confined)

Prognosis.text: Tumor confined to endometrium at diagnosis in only ~ 10%
30-40% overall survival rate; 40% of endometrial cancer-related deaths
Survival up to 90% if confined to endometrium
Low survival rates (< 15%) if stage III or IV
Frequent peritoneal and lymph node metastases (up to 45%) without myometrial invasion
High recurrence rate, including stage I and II tumors

General Features.text: Normal to small-sized or enlarged uterus
May not be visible and confined to endometrial polyp
Irregular polypoid/papillary appearance coating endometrium
Diffuse thickening of myometrial wall
± necrosis &/or hemorrhage

Histologic Features.text: Papillary growth (most common)Irregularly shaped, medium to large branching papillae, small papillae (less common) ± micropapillary component, and cellular budding (as noncohesive cells) with ragged luminal contours
sub_points: Irregularly shaped, medium to large branching papillae, small papillae (less common) ± micropapillary component, and cellular budding (as noncohesive cells) with ragged luminal contours

Histologic Features.text: Solid growthClosely packed nests and sheets
sub_points: Closely packed nests and sheets

Histologic Features.text: Slit-like spaces secondary to compact papillary growth or poorly formed glands
May only involve endometrial polyp(s) or surface endometrium
Prominent nuclear pseudostratification lacking nuclear polarity
± psammoma bodies (much less common than in ovarian/peritoneal counterparts)
Myometrial invasion, gaping gland morphology frequent (no stromal response)
± lymphovascular invasion (often seen as small, round papillae with psammoma bodies) in absence of prominent myometrial invasion
± other high-grade subtype of endometrial carcinoma
May partially or completely replace preexisting endometrial glands (serous intraepithelial carcinoma)
Often background atrophic endometrium

Cytologic Features.text: Noncohesive cells with eosinophilic (focally clear) cytoplasm or hobnail cells
High nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
High-grade nuclear atypia with hyperchromatic and pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli ± multinucleated tumor cells
Brisk mitotic activity (> 10/10 HPF) with atypical mitoses common

Overlapping nuclei resembling papillary thyroid carcinoma

Syncytial Papillary or Atypical Tubal Me.text: Syncytial metaplasia: No cytoplasmic borders, rare mitoses in background of stromal breakdown
Tubal metaplasia: Uniform cytologic features with rare mitoses and cilia

Reactive Epithelial Changes.text: Often in background of infarcted polyp
Focal and often on surface lacking mitoses; p53 wild type

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Any serous component should be reported as presence likely has prognostic implications
If unsure about serous component in biopsy/curettage, note should include that possibility, as surgical management may differ from endometrioid carcinoma

Lack of HER2 concordance between endometrial biopsy/curettage and hysterectomy in endometrial serous carcinoma likely due to heterogeneity of staining and fixation issues; testing of multiple specimens may identify larger number of patients eligible for targeted therapy

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Evaluate high-power cytologic features in "gland-forming" endometrial carcinoma: Lack of smooth luminal border and nuclear polarity, noncohesive cells, and high-grade nuclear features that do not correlate with glandular architecture favor serous carcinoma

If no tumor grossly seen but polyp identified in hysterectomy specimen of postmenopausal woman with atypical cells suspicious for serous carcinoma on Papanicolaou smear, polyp should be completely submitted for histologic examination
Although serous carcinoma shows mutant p53 and diffuse p16 positivity, these features may be seen in other endometrial carcinoma subtypes; thus, morphologic correlation needed

POLE-mutated endometrioid carcinomas may closely mimic serous carcinomas morphologically as ambiguous and may be p53 mutated, also often scattered giant cells and prominent tumor-infiltrating lymphocytesBefore making diagnosis of serous carcinoma, if most typical morphology not present, consider POLE testing
sub_points: Before making diagnosis of serous carcinoma, if most typical morphology not present, consider POLE testing

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Always investigate extrauterine origin (ovary, tube, or peritoneum) in any endometrial low-grade papillary serous neoplasm
If synchronous tumors in endometrium and fallopian tube/ovary, evaluate amount of endometrial tumor as well as WT1 and ER profile
When making diagnosis of serous carcinoma, always exclude component of carcinosarcoma

When evaluating omental biopsies for metastatic serous carcinoma, those of tuboovarian origin show more often varied architectural patterns than those arising from endometrium; although immunohistochemical stains not reliable, WT1(-) would favor endometrial primary
Caution in utilization of HNF-1-β and napsin A in differential diagnosis of serous and clear cell carcinomas as former often HNF-1-β(+) and may be napsin A (+)

Although, differential diagnosis between serous carcinomas and melanoma in endometrium typically straightforward, at metastatic sites both may have solid growth; PRAME (preferentially expressed antigen in melanoma) expressed in most serous carcinomas; thus, this marker relatively nonspecific in this differential diagnosis
